key_points: Facebook announced the removal of disinformation networks linked to various global actors, including Hamas, Chinese state groups, and anti-vaccine organizations.
The removals are part of Facebook's ongoing efforts to combat disinformation, which began intensively after the 2016 Russian election interference.
The company has targeted hundreds of takedowns involving diverse groups, from political organizations to disinformation-for-hire firms.
Critics, including a Facebook whistleblower, accuse the company of neglecting domestic disinformation campaigns, especially in strategically important countries.
Facebook's practices relating to the handling of disinformation were highlighted in the 'Facebook Papers,' revealing a contrast with CEO Mark Zuckerberg's public statements.
The China-related operation involved a fake account of a Swiss biologist claiming U.S. pressure on WHO scientists, which was amplified by Chinese state-controlled media.
Facebook linked some disinformation efforts about the Belarus-Poland border crisis to the Belarusian KGB, aiming to criticize Poland's treatment of migrants.
In Gaza, a Hamas-led disinformation campaign was aimed at garnering support for Hamas while criticizing Israel and its political rivals.
Facebook is striving to adapt to evolving tactics by adversarial groups, citing crackdowns on anti-vaccination harassment campaigns in Europe as examples.
The report shows Facebook's complex battle against disinformation, stressing the global scale of the issue and the platform's central role.
